name: Abrotanum
Relationship: Compare: Scrophularia; Bryonia; Stellaria; Benzoic acid, in gout. Iodine, Nat-m. in marasmus.

Respiratory: Pain in lumbar region extending along spermatic cord
Stomach: Pain in stomach; worse at night; cutting, gnawing pain
Indigestion, with vomiting of large quantities of offensive fluid
Stomach feels as if swimming in water; feels cold
Abdomen: Sensation as if bowels were sinking down
Hemorrhoids; frequent urging; bloody stools; worse as rheumatic pains abate
Skin: Eruptions come out on face; are suppressed, and the skin becomes purplish
Extremities: Pricking and coldness in fingers and feet
Pain in shoulders, arms, wrists, and ankles

details: A very useful remedy in MARASMUS, especially of lower extremities only, yet with good appetite. METASTASIS. Rheumatism following checked diarrhoea. Ill effects of suppressed conditions especially in gouty subjects. Tuberculous peritonitis. EXUDATIVE PLEURISY and other exudative processes. After operation upon the chest for hydrothorax or empyema, a pressing sensation remains. Aggravation of hemorrhoids when rheumatism improves. Nosebleed and hydrocele in boys.Great weakness after influenza (Kali-p.)
